instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2838: What is 820-2838? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.U7201: What is U7201? U7201 is responsible for the 3.3v and 5v power rails on many devices..
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2838</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a not turning on
threads.message:
I have a green light on the charger no fan spining. I've checked every rail.
the only rails present are <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
  <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>
 I don't have any S0,S3,S5 power rails

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2838</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a not turning on
threads.message: Check 3V S5 on L7260 first. If that is ok then disconnect the trackpad cable and short the power button pads (<RESISTOR>R5014</RESISTOR>, 5015)

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2838</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a not turning on
[SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2838</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a not turning on
threads.message: Well, check around <CHIP>U7201</CHIP>, should be 3V on L7260.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2838</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a not turning on
threads.message: checked nothin 0v <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H_OR_PBUS</SIGNAL> is 16v is it ok? in the schematic it show that it has to be 18.5

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2838</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a not turning on
threads.message: On <CHIP>U7201</CHIP> i have on en 3.4v and en1 0v

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2838</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a not turning on
threads.message: Yes, but the only one that matters would be EN2!

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2838</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a not turning on
threads.message:
EN2 is 1.7v
If i have just a green light in the charger and nothing is working what i have to troubleshoot first? S0 rails? â€‹these are "G3Hot" (Always-Present) Rails
<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_S5_S5</SIGNAL> 16.7v
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 8.4v
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H_ISNS</SIGNAL> 8.38v
<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> 3.42v

The S0,S3,S5 rails nothing not one of them

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2838</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a not turning on
threads.message: So EN2 is there and there is nothing on <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>. Use some brains here.....Either <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> is shorted or <CHIP>U7201</CHIP> is dead.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2838</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a not turning on
